dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, the US Inflation Reduction Act, the IRA, right? It's been a pretty big deal. But, uh, Europe seems a bit… conflicted about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, the U S Inflation Reduction Act, the I R A, right? It's been a pretty big deal. But, uh, Europe seems a bit conflicted about it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while the US decision to join the global fight against climate change has been well received in the European Union, some leaders have voiced concerns that the bill focuses too much on domestic production and might discriminate against EU-based companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. On one hand, they like the US re-engaging on climate. But then there's this underlying worry that it's, like, too focused domestically, you know? And might actually hit EU companies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. On one hand, they like the U S re-engaging on climate. But then there's this underlying worry that it's, like, too focused domestically, you know? And might actually hit E U companies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while the US decision to join the global fight against climate change has been well received in the European Union, some leaders have voiced concerns that the bill focuses too much on domestic production and might discriminate against EU-based companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But this article argues, actually, that Europe shouldn't resist it. They should, uh, actually embrace it and make their *own* version, a better one.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But this article argues, actually, that Europe shouldn't resist it. They should, uh, actually embrace it and make their own version, a better one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a recent policy paper, I argue that Europe should not resist the new US approach to climate policy. Instead, European countries should welcome it and develop a better version of their own.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which I found super interesting. Because it points out the IRA moves beyond just, um, carbon pricing – which is what the EU's Fit for 55 really leans on, right? It's more about targeted investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which I found super interesting. Because it points out the I R A moves beyond just, um, carbon pricing - which is what the E U's Fit for fifty five really leans on, right? It's more about targeted investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs current approach, exemplified by its Fit for 55 initiative, adheres to a market-based paradigm that relies on carbon pricing to ensure self-regulation by emitters. The IRA, by contrast, assumes that a forward-looking government can accelerate the transition to a green economy through targeted investment subsidies to people and companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Like, a forward-looking government actually accelerating the green transition through subsidies, not just, you know, relying on market self-regulation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Like, a forward-looking government actually accelerating the green transition through subsidies, not just, you know, relying on market self-regulation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs current approach, exemplified by its Fit for 55 initiative, adheres to a market-based paradigm that relies on carbon pricing to ensure self-regulation by emitters. The IRA, by contrast, assumes that a forward-looking government can accelerate the transition to a green economy through targeted investment subsidies to people and companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it's got this really strong pro-worker bent, too. Thinking about domestic jobs, trying to boost wages by making tax credits conditional. [interrupts] Which is pretty smart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's got this really strong pro-worker bent, too. Thinking about domestic jobs, trying to boost wages by making tax credits conditional. Which is pretty smart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the IRA has a clear pro-worker bent, focusing on domestic employment and attempting to boost wages by making some tax credits conditional on companies commitment to pay prevailing wages.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, that's a big one! Because the article argues the EU's market-liberal approach, um, neglects crucial features of human societies, like individual adjustment costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a big one! Because the article argues the E U's market-liberal approach, um, neglects crucial features of human societies, like individual adjustment costs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the EUs market-liberal approach is bound to fail, because the economic theory that underpins it neglects two crucial features of human societies: individual adjustment costs and economic power relationships.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It says that the IRA's targeted, government-focused approach is actually based on sound economic reasoning, unlike the kind of 'fairytale world of free markets' that some EU policymakers are, like, enthralled by.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It says that the I R A's targeted, government-focused approach is actually based on sound economic reasoning, unlike the kind of fairytale world of free markets that some E U policymakers are, like, enthralled by.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And while European policymakers seem enthralled by the fairytale world of free markets, the IRAs targeted, government-focused approach is based on sound economic reasoning.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so IRA good, in theory. But it does have a big flaw, right? The US kinda lacks the labor institutions to *really* make that pro-worker agenda work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so I R A good, in theory. But it does have a big flaw, right? The U S kinda lacks the labor institutions to really make that pro-worker agenda work.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But while the IRAs overall approach to climate policy is sound, it does have one major flaw. Simply put, the US lacks the labor institutions necessary to translate a pro-worker government agenda into actual policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's it! Like, unions, work councils, minimum wage enforcement... the US isn't quite there. But that's where Europe has this *huge* advantage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's it! Like, unions, work councils, minimum wage enforcement... the U S isn't quite there. But that's where Europe has this huge advantage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Addressing the structural power asymmetry between workers and employers requires well-organized unions, work councils, and stronger enforcement of minimum-wage laws. ... Clearly, when it comes to developing a labor-friendly climate agenda, many European countries have an advantage over the US that they can and must leverage.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! So instead of complaining, they should leverage what they already have. Collective bargaining, [interrupts] uh, union wages as benchmarks...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! So instead of complaining, they should leverage what they already have. Collective bargaining, uh, union wages as benchmarks...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In most EU countries, industrial wages are covered by collective-bargaining agreements, and union wages could easily be used as benchmarks in other sectors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] ...and those amazing apprenticeship programs, like in Germany! That's a natural fit for building a skilled green workforce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...and those amazing apprenticeship programs, like in Germany! That's a natural fit for building a skilled green workforce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Germany and several other EU countries have a long tradition of using apprenticeships and retraining programs to support workers in acquiring the technical skills needed for most industrial jobs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the minimum wage, too. I mean, Germany just raised theirs, but the article says they need to go even further, like to €16, to really set an example.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the minimum wage, too. I mean, Germany just raised theirs, but the article says they need to go even further, like to sixteen euros, to really set an example.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The German government recently took an important step in this direction when it raised the minimum wage from 10,45 to 12 ... In line with the EUs recent declaration on minimum wages, Germany must raise its minimum wage to at least 16 as soon as possible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's about using this green energy transition as an opportunity to, um, not just green the economy, but make it fairer for workers, too. A robust, pro-worker response.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's about using this green energy transition as an opportunity to, um, not just green the economy, but make it fairer for workers, too. A robust, pro-worker response.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU countries must use the green-energy transition as an opportunity to set a fair minimum wage that provides a decent standard of living. ... By doing so, it could help push the whole EU toward a robust pro-worker response to the IRA.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, don't hate the player, hate the game... or rather, learn from the player and make your own game even better.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, don't hate the player, hate the game... or rather, learn from the player and make your own game even better.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much! A 'better version of their own,' as the author puts it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much! A better version of their own, as the author puts it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, European countries should welcome it and develop a better version of their own.
